results.title: Smithy
results.creator_credit: Columbia Pictures, N.P. Pery and Ken G. Hall
results.brief_description: This biography of pioneering aviator Sir Charles Kingsford Smith was modelled on the Hollywood biopic, and the Cinesound production team’s smooth professionalism matched Hollywood production values. The emphasis is on Smithy’s heroism, and although some conflict is provided by his doubts and domestic problems, the filmmakers seem to be more interested in Smithy’s obsessive quest for perfection. The Pacific flight, the peak of his achievement, rather than his final disappearance, provides an appropriate climax. Smithy’s old plane, the Southern Cross was resurrected from storage and flown by two of its old pilots. The film is also notable for the appearance of former Prime Minister William Morris Hughes as himself. Cast includes Ron Randell as Smithy and Muriel Steinbeck as Lady Kingsford Smith.

results.title: Smiley's people
results.creator_credit: BBC-TV, Jonathon Powell and Simon Langton
results.brief_description: John Le Carre’s character Smiley is bought to life by Sir Alec Guinness in this acclaimed dramatisation. Compulsive viewing to the end, Smiley is called out of retirement to the aid of the Circus. He returns with a vengeance. The assassination of an emigre Soviet and British agent, General Vladimir, sends Smiley delving into the past on a twisted trail across Europe that moves inexorably towards a final showdown with his old adversary and arch-enemy, Karla - leader of Moscow centre.

results.title: Smiles of a summer night
results.brief_description: This film marked a milestone in Bergman’s career and his success with international audiences allowed him this foray into romantic comedy. Forming the basis for Stephen Sondheim’s musical ‘ A Little night music’, this is the story of a middle-aged lawyer, his inexperienced young wife and her step-so, who are all invited to spend the weekend at the country mansion of a beautiful actress, the lawyer’s ex-mistress. During the course of the weekend three couples meet, exchange partners and provide some lively comedic action, illustrating Bergman’s sardonic attitude towards the vagaries of love. Behind the scintillating and witty approach to this charming period comedy of manners lie the illusions and pretensions of the haute bourgeois which Bergman cleverly illistrates with his collection of fickle husbands and scheming women.

results.title: Smile of Buddha
results.creator_credit: Office de Radiodiffusion Television Francais, UNICEF and Yves Gautier
results.brief_description: The sparrows of Saigon of the opening song refer to the thousands of homeless and injured children of this city, who are both victims of the war or whose already miserable condition the war has worsened. Orphanages and hospitals provide some of these children with food and care. Various nurses and organisers in these places, speak about the children, their work, and children are shown as they talk, play or are treated.

results.title: Smile for auntie
results.creator_credit: Weston Woods Studios, Morton Schindel and Gene Deitch
results.brief_description: A gently wicked satiric animated look at an aunt’s attempt to make baby smile. About the strange behaviour adults indulge in when attempting to communicate with, and relate to an infant. The aunt is seen from a child’s eye view. From the book written and illustrated by Diane Paterson. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Smash palace
results.creator_credit: Aardvark Films, New Zealand Film Commission and Roger Donaldson
results.brief_description: Smash Palace is a remarkable drama about a marital breakup which erupts into an impulsive kidnapping of a child by the father, and a totally credible escalation to the brink of tragedy. Bruno Lawrence and Anna Jemison play the estranged couple in strong performances. Filmed amongst a vast junk-yard of cars, Donaldson’s direction is economical and enthralling, capturing the tension that goes beneath the surface of this all too real drama.

results.title: Smart footwork
results.creator_credit: Renown Pictures, Palfreeman Film Productions and Toby Carpenter
results.brief_description: It is said that a man spends half of his life in his shoes, yet gives them less thought than any other article of apparel. Here in this film we watch the process of manufacture of footwear in a British factory, starting with the evil-smelling tannery where the hides are treated, and ending wiht someone’s feet in a smart pair of finished shoes. The film shows also examples of footwear worn as long ago as the 15th century, and watch master craftsmen at work on hand-made shoes.

results.title: Smallpox: merciless traveller
results.creator_credit: Czechoslovak Film Studios, World Health Organisation and Vaclav Bedrich
results.brief_description: This animated film deals with the history of smallpox throughout the ages. Shows how it has ravaged the world from the time of the Pharoahs, the discovery of a vaccine by Edward Jenner and his fight to have it recognised by international medical authorities and how the smallpox problem is being dealt with in the present day.

results.title: Small world = Le Monde est petit
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Unesco and Jacques Valentin
results.brief_description: Children from some forty countries were asked to give their interpretation in drawings of the world from pre-history to the year 3000 AD. This film, made within the framework of UNESCO’s project for the mutual understanding of Orient and Occident, shows that the imagination of children knows no frontiers.
